      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <h2 dir="auto">Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification</h2>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Specification Title: User Agent Client Hints</li>
<li>Specification or proposal URL: <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-ua-client-hints-00" rel="nofollow">https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-ua-client-hints-00</a></li>
<li>Mozillians who can provide input: <a class="user-mention" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/martinthomson/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/martinthomson">@martinthomson</a> , <a class="user-mention" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/annevk/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/annevk">@annevk</a></li>
</ul>
<h3 dir="auto">Other information</h3>
<p dir="auto">The <code>User Agent</code> header that is being sent today on every request provides an excellent source of entropy that can be used to passively fingerprint users. It would be great if browsers could stop sending that information by default to all servers, regardless of whether those servers need it or not.</p>
<p dir="auto">The <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-ua-client-hints-00" rel="nofollow">User Agent Client Hint proposal</a> is destined to replace the <code>User Agent</code> header, to achieve the following:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Send significantly less information by default (only the browser brand and major version).</li>
<li>Split the current entropy-laden string into several separate hints/attributes, enabling servers to request some information (e.g. minor version number), without being exposed to other information (e.g. CPU architecture).</li>
<li>Enable 1P servers to opt-in to receive that information as HTTP request headers, as well as in a JS API, while giving 3P servers access to that information only if delegated from the 1P.</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">The above will enable browsers to keep track of servers that collect that information, and take actions to protect users' privacy in cases where that collection is likely abusing it.</p>
<p dir="auto">Another interesting characteristic of reseting access to the UA string is that it can allow browsers to apply <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-ua-client-hints-00#section-4.2" rel="nofollow">GREASE</a> to the new values, in order to prevent the negative implications of UA sniffing seen on the web today.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>

      <a href="#issuecomment-558294095" id="issuecomment-558294095-permalink" class="Link--secondary js-timestamp"><relative-time datetime="2019-11-25T19:00:40Z" class="no-wrap">Nov 25, 2019</relative-time></a>

<task-lists disabled sortable>
<table class="d-block user-select-contain" data-paste-markdown-skip>
  <tbody class="d-block">
    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">Hey <a class="user-mention" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/yoavweiss/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/yoavweiss">@yoavweiss</a> - sorry for the delay here. I've been having discussions with Tanvi and <a class="user-mention" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/martinthomson/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/martinthomson">@martinthomson</a> about the User Agents Hints proposal and here's some draft language that could maybe result in a position:</p>
<hr>
<h3 dir="auto">Description</h3>
<p dir="auto">The UA Hints proposal aims to solve the following problems associated with the User Agent (UA) string: UA sniffing, UA spoofing, and an entropy-rich target for fingerprinting. The proposal is to build on top of the Client Hints infrastructure and solve these problems over time.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">(Draft) Mozilla's Position</h3>
<p dir="auto">Using Client Hints to deliver info derived from the User Agent header for servers who specifically request this information may reduce the number of parties that can use this information for passively fingerprinting users.  However, we could reduce this even further by freezing the User Agent string and requiring resources to actively request this information via the proposed NavigatorUAData interface JS APIs. This would also allow us to audit the callers. At this time, freezing the User Agent string without any client hints—seems worth-prototyping. We look forward to learning from other vendors who implement the “GREASE-like UA Strings” proposal and its effects on site compatibility.</p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">Less formal version:</p>
<p dir="auto">We're very interested in the freezing UA string stuff and <code>NavigatorUAData</code> JS APIs, and think those are worth prototyping. Personally, the GREASE-like stuff is interesting but slightly scary. I'd love to see Chrome turn that on in Canary at some point and see what happens.</p>
<p dir="auto">But I don't think the positive points change our position on Client HInts (which is currently "non-harmful"). <a class="user-mention" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/martinthomson/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/martinthomson">@martinthomson</a> could probably expound on that.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

        <code>
          <a title="Update UA client hints to harmful

Recent additions to the API increase the information that is made
available to sites with insufficient justification.  Other
characteristics of the proposal have always been uncomfortable, but that
change in particular pushes this proposal into being harmful.  #552
lists other reasons in support of this conclusion.

Our basic position remains unchanged: freezing the UA string is a good
idea, but somewhat challenging (as others have found), providing a
replacement that is only an alternative spelling is not useful and
verges on harmful, deliberately adding fingerprinting information to the
web is harmful.

For #202.
Closes #552." data-pjax="true" class="Link--secondary markdown-title" href="/martinthomson/standards-positions/commit/0041dd995b6593740f117d240008e4bb0dc45e17">Update UA client hints to harmful</a>

    <div class="Details-content--hidden mt-2">
      <pre class="color-fg-muted ws-pre-wrap">Recent additions to the API increase the information that is made
available to sites with insufficient justification.  Other
characteristics of the proposal have always been uncomfortable, but that
change in particular pushes this proposal into being harmful.  <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="942122883" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552">mozilla#552</a>
lists other reasons in support of this conclusion.

Our basic position remains unchanged: freezing the UA string is a good
idea, but somewhat challenging (as others have found), providing a
replacement that is only an alternative spelling is not useful and
verges on harmful, deliberately adding fingerprinting information to the
web is harmful.

For <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="489681764" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/202" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/202/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/202">mozilla#202</a>.
<span class="issue-keyword tooltipped tooltipped-se" aria-label="This commit closes issue #552.">Closes</span> <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="942122883" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552">mozilla#552</a>.</pre>

          <a title="Update UA client hints to harmful (#553)

* Update UA client hints to harmful

Recent additions to the API increase the information that is made
available to sites with insufficient justification.  Other
characteristics of the proposal have always been uncomfortable, but that
change in particular pushes this proposal into being harmful.  #552
lists other reasons in support of this conclusion.

Our basic position remains unchanged: freezing the UA string is a good
idea, but somewhat challenging (as others have found), providing a
replacement that is only an alternative spelling is not useful and
verges on harmful, deliberately adding fingerprinting information to the
web is harmful.

For #202.
Closes #552.

    <div class="Details-content--hidden mt-2">
      <pre class="color-fg-muted ws-pre-wrap">* Update UA client hints to harmful

Recent additions to the API increase the information that is made
available to sites with insufficient justification.  Other
characteristics of the proposal have always been uncomfortable, but that
change in particular pushes this proposal into being harmful.  <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="942122883" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552">#552</a>
lists other reasons in support of this conclusion.

Our basic position remains unchanged: freezing the UA string is a good
idea, but somewhat challenging (as others have found), providing a
replacement that is only an alternative spelling is not useful and
verges on harmful, deliberately adding fingerprinting information to the
web is harmful.

For <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="489681764" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/202" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/202/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/202">#202</a>.
<span class="issue-keyword tooltipped tooltipped-se" aria-label="This commit closes issue #552.">Closes</span> <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="942122883" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/552">#552</a>.

* Editorial tweak</pre>

readabilityObject.title: User Agent Client Hints · Issue #202 · mozilla/standards-positions
readabilityObject.content:
Comments

martinthomson added a commit to martinthomson/standards-positions that referenced this issue

Jul 13, 2021 

Recent additions to the API increase the information that is made
available to sites with insufficient justification.  Other
characteristics of the proposal have always been uncomfortable, but that
change in particular pushes this proposal into being harmful.  mozilla#552
lists other reasons in support of this conclusion.

Our basic position remains unchanged: freezing the UA string is a good
idea, but somewhat challenging (as others have found), providing a
replacement that is only an alternative spelling is not useful and
verges on harmful, deliberately adding fingerprinting information to the
web is harmful.

For mozilla#202.
Closes mozilla#552.

martinthomson added a commit that referenced this issue

Recent additions to the API increase the information that is made

Our basic position remains unchanged: freezing the UA string is a good
idea, but somewhat challenging (as others have found), providing a

verges on harmful, deliberately adding fingerprinting information to the
web is harmful.

For #202.
Closes #552.

* Editorial tweak
